verse: Sometime later, a discontented contingent challenged Moses. Korah (Izhar’s son, Kohath’s grandson, and Levi’s great-grandson) together with the Reubenites Dathan and Abiram (Eliab’s sons) and On (Peleth’s son)
gathered another 250 Israelite men, all of them respectable members of the community, some even chosen leaders, and confronted Moses.
When Moses heard their complaint, he collapsed to the ground, again hoping to divert God’s anger.
Now, Moses was furious.
They all did this. They ignited the censers, put their incense inside, and stood with Moses and Aaron at the opening of the congregation tent where God would meet with them.
But Korah stirred up the people standing there against Moses and Aaron. The glory of the Eternal One was visible to all,
and then the Eternal spoke to Moses and Aaron.
But Moses and Aaron fell down, bowing low before the glory of God.
The Eternal One told Moses,
So Moses picked himself up and went over to Dathan and Abiram, with all Israel’s elders closely behind.

The people hurried to distance themselves from Korah, Dathan, and Abiram and from their tents. Then Dathan and Abiram, along with their wives and children, stepped out of their tents and stood in the openings.
No sooner had Moses finished speaking than the earth split underneath them.
The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them down—them and everything and everyone associated with Korah.
Then, just as suddenly, the ground closed up over them again, and so they perished, taken alive to the land of the dead.
Those who remained ran away, terrified.
A fire shot out from the Eternal One and incinerated the 250 men who were offering the incense on Korah’s behalf.
The Eternal One continued speaking to Moses.
Nevertheless, on the very next day, all of the Israelite people railed against Moses and Aaron.

When the congregation gathered to attack them, Moses and Aaron headed for the congregation tent and stood in front of it. The cloud was there, and the brilliance of the Eternal’s presence was obvious to all.
There, the Eternal One spoke to Moses.
So Aaron rushed into the crowd with his sacred censer, even as people had already begun to suffer the plague. He stood there covering their sins with the incense smoke,
and where he stood, the plague stopped—dead people on one side, the living on the other.
Thus the plague ended as swiftly as it had begun, but a full 14,700 died that day, in addition to all those who died in the Korah affair.
Then Aaron walked back to join Moses in front of the congregation tent since the plague had stopped.
